repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Follows up on some issues in #25550 and (a bunch of) other things

Also includes Vim patches to issues I found while working on things: 8.2.3862, 9.1.{0116,0118,0119,0121,0128,0130} (and 9.1.0117 as a partial patch).

comment_data.body: The only uses of `win_split_flags` add `| WSP_NOENTER`. Maybe we should just move that into the function?
Subjective (especially as `win_split_flags` is static too), but I think I prefer `WSP_NOENTER` being set at the caller's discretion.

Observation: `last_status()` only works for the current tabpage, and is not called for other tabpages when `&laststatus` changes (at least not until they're entered via `enter_tabpage()`).

In the context of `winframe_restore()`, this means if `wp` is in another tabpage, and say, `&laststatus` changed from 3 (global statusline) to something else before it's entered, this may add a statusline to a window that already has a horizontal separator (or vice versa if `&laststatus` is set the other way around).

This doesn't seem to have any observable effect that I can find though, as the frame sizes aren't changed by this, and `last_status()` will fix the hseps/statuslines upon entering it anyway.

`check_split_disallowed(targetwin)` ought to be `check_split_disallowed(wp)` instead, but I'm not convinced checking `b_split_locked` is needed when split-moving anyway; we're not producing new views into a closing buffer by doing it.

I'll probably end up addressing this and others sometime after vim/vim#14109.

`win_comp_pos()` probably isn't needed here after the commit which added `frame_comp_pos()` to `winframe_restore()` (should probably PR that to Vim at some point); at the very least, I didn't add it to `nvim_win_set_config()` because of this.

I believe the reason it's used after `winframe_remove()` and `last_status()` above is because `last_status()` may steal lines from other frames to make room for a missing statusline? I dunno how that's relevant when _removing_ frames, but this ought not to apply to `winframe_restore()`.

Anyways, `win_comp_pos()` is insufficient for a `winframe_restore()` for a `wp` in a different tabpage, as it only works for curtab.

As mentioned in the commit, this would be better off using `{un}use_tabpage`, so `tp_curwin` gets set too. This would address the inconsistency where:

```vim
:call win_execute(w, "let curwin_nr1 = tabpagewinnr(1)")
:let curwin_nr2 = tabpagewinnr(1)
```

Here it's possible for `curwin_nr1 != curwin_nr2` if these commands are run from the 1st tabpage, but window `w` is in the 2nd (as the 1st tabpage's `tp_curwin` may still be invalid).

I'll probably PR a fix for that later in Vim.

comment_regular_data.body: This looks great! I'm working on fixes for some of the [split behavior](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25550#discussion_r1474165527) btw, unless you were planning on doing that.

> This looks great! I'm working on fixes for some of the [split behavior](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25550#discussion_r1474165527) btw, unless you were planning on doing that.

Feel free to work on that! I only plan to address some random things I find here.

> Feel free to work on that! I only plan to address some random things I find here.

Sounds good!

TODO: (partially, 'cuz WinNewPre, which I'm not enthusiastic about porting in its current state _sigh_) port the following patches I've upstreamed to address the WIP in the first commit:

~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/0fd44a5ad81ade342cb54d8984965bdedd2272c8~~
~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/96cc4aef3d47d0fd70e68908af3d48a0dce8ea70~~ (partial)
~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/704966c2545897dfcf426dd9ef946aeb6fa80c38~~
~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/f865895c874b0936b0563ebfef7490aac8cb8a1f~~
~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/02fcae02a926e4e8379d77fb716da4202029882d~~
~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/2a65e739447949a7aee966ce8a3b75521b2a79ea~~
~~https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/abf7030a5c22257f066fa9c4061ad150d5a82577~~

Also it seems it's possible to reduce `&columns` to a size smaller than the minimum topframe width, which can cause Nvim to explode (though for some reason `&lines` already has this check lol)

About time I open this for reviews before the scope increases more :see_no_evil:.

There are a few other things I discovered that I haven't addressed here:

- `tabpagewinnr()` and `nvim_tabpage_get_win()` don't work for non-current tabpages with `tp_curwin`s pointing to external windows (the latter calls `abort()`). This is a consequence of how "tabpage independence" of external windows are implemented (they're moved between tabpages when entering another).

- Unlike the minimum value of `&lines` which is based on the minimum frame height, the minimum value of `&columns` is not based on the minimum frame width. This can cause the assertion `(size_t)grid_line_maxcol <= linebuf_size` in `grid_line_start()` to fail (and maybe other issues) if the frames can't fit:

  `:execute 'vsplit|'->repeat(99) | set columns=12`

- Some of the textlocky API functions probably ought to check `curbuf_locked()` too...

Also, I assume `nvim_win_set_config` is rather unique in its ability to move existing windows between tabpages (unlike stuff like `:wincmd T`, which actually creates a _new_ window).  
Maybe that could cause issues with things using `win_valid` to check if such a window wasn't closed, or if something saves a reference to the tabpage it was in to check later for whatever reason. Haven't investigated this much, though.

I also pushed some follow-up commits. That pending test I added is a bit tricky to fix (as it will likely require changing `close_last_window_tabpage()` and its callsites), so I'll leave it as pending for now.

Thanks for that! :hugs:

After sleeping on things, I've realized there's a few more issues I missed:

- [x] `nvim_win_set_config` should select a new `tp_curwin` if `win` was moved from a different tabpage.

- [x] `winframe_remove` takes a `tp` argument, but its flattening logic references `topframe` (_lolwut_; [Bram also seemed](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/2467#issuecomment-362017894) to be confused by why it's necessary to check it...).
   _This one seems benign, so I won't address it._

- [x] `switch_win` with `no_display` doesn't update the `topframe`, which should be done before `win_split_ins` in `nvim_win_set_config` (actually it's also true for `nvim_open_win`; D'oh!) ([v8.2.3862](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/dab17a0689a2f31f69f428975f84b0c3c7ba3030) :sparkles:).

None of these are regressions from this PR, but they should be addressed before merging. :see_no_evil:
Oh, I have to move some changes out of this PR then.
Its OK, I think I've fixed those issues now. (I'll push in a bit)
I noticed that moving these changes out of the PR still conflicts, so I pushed back to the previous state.

Okie dokie, I've pushed the commits on top of that state (and amended the [`fix(api): win_set_config set tp_curwin of win moved from other tabpage`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27330/commits/b52d15853e89149472c1ecd9cce3a84e4af0785a) one to add a bit more to the test).

Here's the [diff](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/compare/60e978539bc5ff66aacb023528088cfb89cf5559..c3d22d32ee4b4c1911ec15f2a77683d09b09f845) of that.

Ok, I'm totally _over_ this PR at this point. :laughing:

Once checks are green, I'm happy to merge immediately if that sounds good. :+1:
Awesome! Not sure I could have provided any helpful reviews here as a lot of this is beyond my Vim knowledge (for now...) but this PR has been very informative to read through.
Now time to hope I didn't break anything :innocent:

repo.name: neovim

labels.description: issue is fixed in vim and patch needs to be ported
labels.name: has:vim-patch

title: fix(api): various window-related function fixes
